Scheme 1 Synthesis of Fe(II)-NHC complexes. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 The molecular structures of [Fe(L1)Cp(CO)]I 1 (A), [Fe(L2)Cp(CO)]Br 2 (B) and [Fe(L4)Cp(CO)]I 4 (C) (Pov-ray figures drawn from 50% probability factor of the thermal eclipsed). Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Cyclic voltammograms of 1–4 in acetonitrile (1 × 10−3 M). Novel iron(II)-N-heterocyclic carbene catalysts for efficient transfer hydrogenations under mild condition Thukkaiyandi Pradeep a Marappan Velusamy b Ramasamy Mayilmurugan a ⁎ a Bioinorganic Chemistry Laboratory/Physical Chemistry, School of Chemistry, Madurai Kamaraj University, Madurai, 625 021, Tamil Nadu, India Bioinorganic Chemistry Laboratory/Physical Chemistry School of Chemistry Madurai Kamaraj University Madurai Tamil Nadu 625 021 India b Department of Chemistry, North Eastern Hill University, Shillong, 793022, India Department of Chemistry North Eastern Hill University Shillong 793022 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The novel iron(II)-NHC complexes were synthesized and characterized as the catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of carbonyl complexes. The excellent transfer hydrogenations were achieved up to the yield of 99% and TOF of 13,680 h−1 at room temperature. Four novel N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) based Fe(II) complexes, [Fe(L1)Cp(CO)]I (1), [L1 = 3-methyl-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-benzimidazol-2-ylidene], [Fe(L2)Cp(CO)]Br (2) [L2 = 3-benzyl-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-benzimidazol-2-ylidene], [Fe(L3)Cp-(CO)]Br (3), [L3 = 3-(4-tert-butyl-benzyl)-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-benzimidazol-2-ylidene] and [Fe(L4)Cp(CO)]I (4), L4 = 1,3-di-(2- methylenepyridyl methyl)-benzimidazol-2-ylidene] have been synthesized and characterized as efficient catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds. The disappearance of 1H NMR signals at 10.09–11.78 ppm of NHC ligand confirms the complex formation via carbene coordination to low spin Fe(II) center and it is further supported by the two distinct doublets for two diastereotopic protons of the methylene group connects pyridine and benzimidazole rings. The IR spectra show ν str, 1939–1958 cm−1 for the coordinated CO, which are virtually independent of the wingtip substituents and possibly this limits the influence of those groups on the electronic properties of iron(II) center. The molecular structure of the complexes 1, 2 and 4 reveals the coordination of NHC ligand, cyclopentadiene (Cp) and CO to low spin FeII center (S = 0). The bonds Fe-Ccarbene (1.907–1.934 Å), Fe-NPy (1.995–2.019 Å), Fe−CO (1.743–1.762 Å) and Fe-Cp (2.058–2.097 Å) are almost identical in all the complexes. The bite angles CO-Fe-Ccarbene (90.9°– 113.8°) are higher than Cp-Fe-Ccarbene (92.6°–93.2°) but the bite angle CO-Fe-Npy are merely indentical in all complexes (89.7°). All the complexes showed two redox couples at 1.050 - 1.080 V and 0.560 – 0.585 V corresponds to FeII/FeIII and ligand-based redox couples respectively. The complexes exhibited the excellent transfer hydrogenation for aldehydes up to yield of 99% with the turnover frequency (TOF) of 13,680 h−1 at room temperature. The ketone substrates showed conversion of alcohols with the yield and TOF of 98% and 2264 h−1 respectively at 60 °C. Keywords Iron-NHC complexes Catalysis Transfer hydrogenation 1 Introduction The N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHC) are emerging as versatile ligands in organometallic chemistry [[1]]. The strong σ-donating and less-π acceptor nature of NHCs show excellent support to stabilize various oxidation states of complex and thus displays attractive catalytic properties. [[1],[2]] Also, the NHC-bearing transition metal catalysts can give access to unprecedented reactivity pathways and selectivity that were not observed by using other ligands [1a,2a,3]. In recent years the NHC ligands are appearing as alternatives for classical π electron donor ligands such as amines, ethers, and phosphanes. Many important organic transformation reactions were only driven by rare earth precious/coinage metal catalysis. In fact, several NHC-complexes of these rare earth metals such as Rh, Ir, Pd, Pt etc. have been studied extensively as catalysts for various organic transformations [4]. The toxicity issues, less abundance, and expensive criteria offer a new avenue to search for suitable alternatives [5]. Thus, one rational approach is to use naturally gifted metal like iron as it capable to adopting variable oxidation states and tuneable redox potentials. Its usage integrated part of many nature process. The iron-containing enzymes are known play crucial role in several biocatalytic reactions, particularly for activation of molecular hydrogen using [Fe-Ni], [Fe-Fe] hydrogenases and recently discovered [Fe]-only hydrogenase enzyme [6]. In spite, the Fe-NHC-complexes are relatively underexploited for organic transformations, such as hydrogenation, transfer hydrogenation, hydrosilylation, C–H activation [7] and etc. Only fewer FeII-NHC complexes have been reported in earlier stages, which are focused only structural and spectral properties [8–12]. They include hexacarbene [9], tetracarbene [10], tricarbene [11], biscarbene [12] and piano-stool monocarbene with co-ligands cyclopentadienyl and CO [[18]] and pincer FeII/FeIII complexes of 2,6-bis(NHC)pyridine [13,14,15,16]. Brunner and co-workers have reported the ﬁrst iron-catalysed hydrosilylation reaction of carbonyl compounds [17]. Darcel and co-workers have employed cyclopentadienyl iron catalysts for the hydrosilylation of aldehydes and ketone [18]. Later, they used imidazolium-based half sandwich Fe-NHC complexes for hydrosilylation of aldehydes [18a] and imines [20]. Interestingly, Royo and co-workers showed hydrosilylation of activated aldehydes using NHC–iron complexes of an internally tethered Cp ligand [19]. Very recently, Albrecht and co-workers reported an iron(II) piano-stool complexes of the 1,2,3-triazolylidene-based ligand as a catalyst for hydrosilylation of aldehydes and ketones [21]. Surprisingly, most of them are showed moderate catalytic efficiency for the hydrogenations of aldehydes and ketones only at elevated reaction conditions. This article reports the synthesis and characterization of novel low spin Fe(II)-NHC complexes as an efficient catalyst for the transfer hydrogenation of aldehydes and ketones under mild reaction conditions. The present ligand architecture, additional pyridine nitrogen donor property of benzimidazolium based NHC ligands provide important differences to other previously reported catalysts and thus the catalytic performance. Further, this type of benzimidazolium based NHC ligands is relatively underexplored for first row-transition metals, which are expected to provide improved catalytic barrier under mild conditions (cf. below). To our best of knowledge, our report is the novel example of Fe(II)-NHC catalysts for transfer hydrogenation reactions show turnover frequency (TOF) up to 13,680 h−1 at room temperature. No such Fe(II)-NHC catalysts are reported to such catalytic efficiency other than Morris’s iron complexes of P2N2 ligands derived from diamine backbone [22]. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization The NHC ligands L1 - L4 have been synthesized in two steps by the reaction of benzimidazole and 2-chloromethyl pyridine and followed by alkylation. The carbenes are generated in situ by the deprotonation of the picolyl-benzimidazolium salts using Cs2CO3 at 60 °C. Further, these NHC ligands were reacted with the precursor Fe(Cp)(CO)2I (Cp = cyclopentadienyl) at 60 °C to afford desired pure unsymmetrical half-sandwich compounds [Fe(L1)Cp(CO)]I (1), [Fe(L2)Cp(CO)]Br (2), [Fe(L3)Cp(CO)]Br (3) and [Fe(L4)Cp(CO)]I (4) (Scheme 1 ). They were isolated as pure reddish orange solids with the yield of 67–80%. They are a rare example of moisture, air, and light-insensitive compounds. Our synthetic methodology is more convenient than the other previous reports, where the deprotonation of the imidazolium ligands have been mostly achieved by using a strong base like n-BuLi at −70 °C and often a mixture of products reported.8 The formation of 1–4 is confirmed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy through monitoring disappearance of NCHN proton singlet at 10.09–11.78 ppm and a shift in the 13C signal to 198–206 ppm, which indicates the formation of Fe-Ccarbene bond. Further, it is supported by the appearance of two distinct doublets for the two diastereotopic protons of the methylene group connects pyridine and benzimidazole rings. In the free ligands, these methylene groups exhibit a characteristic singlet around 6 ppm in the 1H NMR spectrum. The 13C signals of carbonyl were appeared at 228 ppm and are well shifted to downfield from their respective free ligands. The HRMS spectra of complexes exhibit molecular ion peak corresponding to the respective cationic compounds, 1: [Fe(L1)Cp(CO)]+, m/z, 372.07901; 2: [Fe(L2)Cp(CO)]+, m/z, 448.11014; 3: [Fe(L3)Cp(CO)]+, m/z, 504.17279 and 4: [Fe(L4)Cp(CO)] +, m/z, 449.10522. The suitable red-orange single crystals of 1, 2 and 4 were grown by diffusion of diethyl ether into a dichloromethane solution of the complexes at −5 °C. The axillary ligands carbonyl (CO) and cyclopentadienyl (Cp) are stabilizing low spin and +2 oxidation states of iron respectively [[8]]. The infrared (IR) spectra show the CO vibrations at νstr at 1946, 1939, 1958 and 1944 cm−1 for 1 - 4 respectively. This reveals that CO absorption energies appear to be virtually independent of the wingtip substituents on 1– 4 and expected to limits the influence of those groups on the electronic properties of iron(II) center. The calculated Tolman’s electronic parameters (TEP) of 1 - 4 (2062–2068 cm−1) are almost similar to that of previously reported half-sandwich iron complexes (2071 cm−1)[8a] and phosphorus ligand.[26] These values are indicating that the donor ability of present carbene ligands is almost identical to that of more basic phosphine-based ligands. 2.2 Molecular structure of complexes The molecular structure of 1 contains two crystallographically independent half-sandwich iron(II) complex molecules with same chemical formula within the asymmetric unit cell (Fig. 1 ). They exhibit the identical geometrical arrangements but with slightly different bond lengths and bond angles. However only one molecule present in the unit cell of 2 and 4 (Fig. 1) The FeCcarbene bond distances are almost identical in 1 (1.919 Å) and 2 (1.934 Å), which are longer than 4 (1.907 Å) (Table 1). These Fe-Ccarbene bonds are shorter than those of previously reported piano-stool half-sandwich iron complexes (1.97–2.01 Å)8 and other related complexes of monodentate carbene ligands with pseudo-octahedral geometries (1.97–1.99 Å).[8,19,25] The shorter Fe-Ccarbene bonds resulted from the stronger p-orbital overlapping of carbon with d-orbitals of iron(II) centre.[23] The Fe−CO bond length is slightly shorter in 1 (1.756 Å) than that of 2 (1.762 Å) but slightly longer than 4 (1.743 Å). The shorter Fe−CO bond in 4 indicates the stronger Fe−CO π-back bonding than 1–3. This is due to the presence of additional methylenepyridyl arm on wingtip of ligand, but this difference is not significantly revealed in the IR and NMR spectral signatures. However, the observed Fe−CO bond lengths in 1, 2 and 4 are falling in the range reported for piano-stool iron complexes (1.71–1.76 Å) [8,14,15,25]. Interestingly, the Fe-NPy bond distance in 1 (1.992 Å) is shorter than 2 (2.019 Å) and 4 (2.011 Å) but they are well fit in the ranges of FeNpy bond distances of piano-stool half-sandwich iron complexes (1.974–2.0 Å).[8,14,15,25] The Cp ring is coordinated in a η5-fashion with iron(II) centre and Fe-Cp bond distances are slightly varied (1, 2.058; 2, 2.097; 3, 2.071 Å). However, Fe-Cp bond distances are longer than those of piano-stool half-sandwich iron complexes (∼1.73 Å)[8] and closer to Fe-Cp* bond distances of Royo’s complexes (∼2.09 Å).[19] The Cp-Fe-Ccarbene bond angles are almost equal (∼120°), which indicates that the orientation of the carbene ligands is not twisted with respect to Cp ligand (Table 1 ). 2.3 Electrochemical properties The redox behaviour of the complexes was studied by cyclic voltammetry in acetonitrile. A platinum sphere was as a working electrode, a platinum wire, and Ag/Ag + was used as, auxiliary and reference electrodes respectively. The NBu4ClO4 (TBAP) was used as a supporting electrolyte. The complexes 1–4 undergo quasi-reversible one-electron oxidation and shows two redox couples corresponding to FeII/FeIII and ligand-based redox (LBR) process around 1.050 – 1.080 V and 0.560 V – 0.585 V vs NHE respectively (Fig. 2 , Table 2). The FeII/FeIII redox potential of the complexes is not significantly influenced by the wingtip variation on ligands. The very similar trend was also observed by IR and NMR spectroscopy. Further, FeII/FeIII the redox potentials of 1– 4 are more positive than that of previously reported half-sandwich iron complexes [[8],19d]. This indicates more electron density around iron(II)-centre influenced by NHC ligands and expected to display higher Lewis acidity. Lever’s electrochemical parameter (EL) of the NHC ligands L1 - L4 have been calculated by the following approximation that the ligand contributions are additive and zero contribution from synergistic and steric factors [24]. The Lever’s electrochemical parameter EL values (LEP) of the ligands were obtained by fitting low-spin FeII/FeIII redox potentials E 1/2 (E obs) into the least-square equation E obs = 1.11(∑EL) −0.43 [8a,25]. The EL values of L1 - L3 are almost identical (0.24–0.26 V) and higher than that of L4 (0.17 V). The relatively lower EL values of ligand L4 is due to the additional methylenepyridyl wingtip and expected to stabilize FeIII of FeII/FeIII redox couple in 4 [8a,25]. The σ donation of carbenes is generally stronger and our results also suggest apparently stronger π back-bonding in the FeII-NHC complexes. On the other hand, one electron reduction of 1 – 4 exhibits FeII/FeI and ligand-based redox (LBR) couples around 0.964–1.010 V and 0.520 – 0.595 V vs NHE respectively (Fig. S21, Table 2 ). This reduction potential of iron NHC complexes is lower than their respective one-electron oxidation potential of FeII/FeIII redox couples. 2.4 Catalytic transfer hydrogenation The catalytic transfer hydrogenations of various aldehydes were performed using 0.088 mol% of 1, isopropanol as the hydrogen source and KOtBu as a base (10 equivalents to 1) at room temperature. The progress of the reactions was monitored and quantified by GC–MS and 1HNMR. The aldehydes were converted into desired alcohol products up to the yield of 56–99% in 5 min. The substrate benzaldehyde showed excellent conversion up to 98% with turn over frequency (TOF) of 13,164 h−1. However, relatively poor transfer hydrogenation has been observed for ketone substrates (10–40%) using 1 under identical conditions at room temperature. Whereas, on raising the reaction temperature to 60 °C resulted in enhancement of alcohols yields up to 99% with TOF, 2264 h−1 over 30 min, which is still significantly lower than those of aldehyde substrates at room temperature. On replacing methyl substituent on wingtip of 1 by benzyl to obtain 2, showed relatively higher TOF (13,680 h−1) for benzaldehyde. On other hand, the catalyst 2 and its tert-butyl derivative 3, were afforded almost similar catalytic efficiency for aldehydes and ketones irrespective of electronic substituents. They showed yields of 58–99% with TOF range of 7776–13,476 h−1 for the conversion of aldehydes into corresponding alcohol in 5 min at room temperature. As expected, relatively poor yields have been determined for the transfer hydrogenation of ketone substrates into corresponding alcohol at room temperature under identical conditions (Table S3 and S4). But, on increasing the reaction temperature to 60 °C, the TOF for the conversion of the ketone into alcohols were enhanced up to 2264 h−1 over 30 min. Nevertheless, the TOFs exhibited by 2 and 3 for ketone are lower than those of aldehyde substrates. The compound 4 shown slight decreased in catalytic efficiency for benzaldehyde. But, the catalytic efficiencies of other aldehydes and ketones are almost identical. However, the changes of wingtip substituents on the ligand architecture showed no concomitant implications of the catalytic efficiencies for aldehydes and ketones with electron donating and withdrawing substituents (Tables 3,4 : entry 2–8). Overall, the present iron(II)-NHC complexes exhibited remarkably efficient transfer hydrogenations with the highest yield of 99% and TOFs of 13,680 h-1 for aldehydes at room temperature under neat reaction conditions. All the reactions required very low catalyst loading and shorter reaction time. The plot of Hammett parameter (σp) of variously substituted benzaldehyde versus TOF shows a less dependence of electronic disparity of the substrate (Fig. S16). The ketone substrates were converted into alcohols with a maximum yield of 98% and TOF, 2264 h−1 at 60 °C. Thus, these catalytic efficiencies are higher at room temperature than the previous reports. In fact, the most of the hydrogenation reactions of aldehyde by iron-NHC complexes were carried out at a higher temperature [13,18a]. Particularly, Royo and co-workers have reported catalytically active piano stool complex [(Cp*-NHC)Fe(CO)(NCMe)]-SO3CF3 (Cp*-NHC = N-heterocyclic carbene ligand with a tetramethylcyclo-pentadienyl ring) for the reduction of benzaldehyde and acetophenone using phenylsilane under neat conditions at 60 °C and above [19]. Albrecht and co-workers showed hydrosilylation of aldehydes and ketones by piano-stool iron(II) complexes at 60 °C [21]. Gosh and co-workers [25] have studied cationic complexes [Cp(i-Pr)Fe(CO)2]I (i-Pr = 1,3-di-(i-Pr)-imidazol-2-ylidene), which are analogous to 1–4. However, the catalysts are active only at 30–70 °C under visible light irradiation. In contrast to this, our present catalysts have exhibited the excellent transfer hydrogenation for aldehydes and ketones up to 99% yield with the highest TON and TOF (13,680 h−1) at room temperature without any light irradiation. Recently Özdemir and co-workers reported a catalyst [Cp(NHC)Fe(CO)2]I containing benzyl-substituted imidazolin-2-ylidene, which shows catalytic reduction of carbonyl compounds only at 100 °C [27]. Casey and Guan have reported Knolker type NHC iron complexes for successive hydrogenation of ketones with molecular hydrogen over 20 h and mixture of alcohol products were reported [28]. 3 Conclusions The novel FeII-NHC-carbene complexes of the type [Fe(L)Cp(CO)]+ have been synthesized and characterized as efficient catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds at relatively lower temperature. The NMR and IR spectra are virtually independent of the wingtip substituents on complexes and limit the influence of those groups on the electronic properties of iron(II) center. The molecular structure of the complexes reveals the coordination of ligand, Cp and the CO to low spin FeII center (S0). The bonds FeCcarbene, FeCp and FeCO are falling in the range reported for piano-stool iron complexes. The complexes have exhibited higher positive FeII/FeIII redox couples. The complexes are found to be excellent catalysts and showed the transfer hydrogenation for aldehydes up to yield of 99% with the highest TOF (13,680 h−1) at room temperature. The ketone substrates were converted into corresponding alcohols with the yield and TOF of 98% and 2264 h−1 respectively at 60 °C. 4 Experimental section 4.1 Materials Benzimidazole, 2-(chloromethyl) pyridine hydrochloride, methyl iodide, benzyl bromide, 4-tert butyl benzyl bromide and cyclopentadienyl iron dicarbonyl iodide were purchased from Aldrich. Benzaldehyde, acetophenone and their all substituents were purchased from Aldrich, Alfa asear, and Avra chemicals. Acetylthiphene, 2-acetylnapthone, benzophenone, picolinaldehyde were purchased from Aldrich. Potassium hydroxide, THF, and dichloromethane were purchased from Merck India. Cesium carbonate purchased from spectrochem. 4.2 Physical measurements The solvents used in this studied were distilled prior to use by following standard purification methods. All reactions were carried out under Ar atmosphere using the standard Schlenk line. Glassware was dried prior to use. The NMR spectra were recorded on 300 MHz Bruker instrument. Chemical shift value and coupling constant mention by ppm and Hz respectively. ESI-Mass spectra were recorded using Thermo LCMS and HRMS recorded on Thermo Scientific Exactive Plus EMR instrument. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was performed using a three-electrode cell configuration. A platinum sphere (acetonitrile medium), platinum wire and Ag(s)/Ag+ were used as working, auxiliary and reference electrodes respectively. The TBAP used as supporting electrolyte in acetonitrile. GC–MS measurements were carried out on Agilent 7820 A instrument. IR spectra were recorded on Thermo Nicolet 6700 IR spectrometer. 4.3 X-ray crystal structure analysis Single crystals of 1, 2, and 4 of suitable size were selected from the mother liquor and immersed in paraffin oil, then mounted on the tip of a glass fibre. Single crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on Agilent Technologies Supernova-E CCD diffractometer. Crystal of complexes was mounted on an STOE image plate diffraction system equipped with a φ circle goniometer, using Mo-Kα graphite monochromated radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-2013. Refinement and all further calculations were carried out using SHELXL-2013. The H-atoms were included in calculated positions and treated as riding atoms using the SHELXL default parameters. The non-H atoms were refined anisotropically, using weighted full-matrix least-square on F2 . CCDC 1572734, 1572730 and CCDC 1572733 are containing the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via ww.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data request/cif. 4.4 Synthesis of ligands 4.4.1 3-methyl-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-1H-benzo[d]imidazol-3-iumiodide (L1) The ligand 3-methyl-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-1H-benzo[d]imidazol-3-iumiodide was synthesized by following known procedure with suitable modifications [29]. The mixture of benzimidazole (0.59 g, 5 mmol), 2-chloromethyl pyridine hydrochloride (0.82 g, 5 mmol) and KOH (0.86 g, 15 mmol) in THF (30 mL) was refluxed for two days at 60°C. After completion of the reaction, it was cooled to room temperature and the solvent was evaporated under vacuum. The viscous solid was dissolved in dichloromethane and filtered through celite followed by water wash. After separation, the organic layer was evaporated to yield the pale-yellow color solid. Without further purification, obtained product was alkylated by the dropwise addition of methyl iodide (0.28 mL, 4 mmol) in 20 mL of toluene. This reaction mixture was refluxed for overnight at 50°C. The evaporation of solvent and then washed with diethyl ether (3 × 10 mL) to obtain a product as a white powder, yield, 1.5 g (86%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 10.09 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1 H), 8.50 (s, 1 H), 7.92 (d, J = 6.2 Hz, 2 H), 7.83 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 1 H), 7.692 (dd, J = 12.9, 7.4 Hz, 3 H), 7.36 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 1 H), 5.91 (s, 2 H), 4.23 (s, 3 H). 13C NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 157.07 (s), 154.93 (s), 147.57 (s), 142.74 (s), 136.95 (s), 136.40 (s), 132.44 (s), 129.14 (s), 128.60 (s), 119.25 (s), 118.48 (s), 57.20 (s), 39.69 (s). ESI-MS (m/z) 351.82. 4.4.2 3-benzyl-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-1H-benzo[d]imidazol-3-ium bromide (L2) The ligand L2 was synthesized using the procedure employed for the ligand L1 using benzyl bromide (0.68 g, 4 mmol) instead of methyl iodide. Yield, 1.7 g (89%). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 11.78 (s, 1 H), 8.49 (d, J = 4.7 Hz, 1 H), 7.91 (d, J = 6.4 Hz, 2 H), 7.76 (t, J = 7.7 Hz, 1 H), 7.52 (dd, J = 12.9, 7.8 Hz, 5 H), 7.38 (d, J = 6.9 Hz, 4 H), 6.05 (s, 2 H), 5.82 (s, 2 H). 13C NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) δ 156.84 (s), 154.42 (s), 142.30 (s), 137.56 (s), 135.75 (s), 133.93 (s), 132.99 (s), 128.34 (d, J = 44.9 Hz), 128.05 (s), 118.97 (s), 118.42 – 118.00 (m), 56.31 (s). ESI-MS (m/z) 381.32. 4.4.3 3-(4-(tert-butyl)benzyl)-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-1H-benzo[d]-imidazol-3-ium-bromide (L3) The ligand L3 was also synthesized by following the above procedure using 4-trtiary butyl-benzyl bromide (0.90 g, 4 mmol) instead of methyl iodide. The reaction mixture was stirred for two days at 60°C. The product formation was periodically monitored by thin layer chromatography and the solvent was removed after completion of reaction. IR - ν CO 1944 cm−1. 5 Transfer hydrogenation reactions The mixture of catalyst (7 μmol), aldehyde/ketone (0.849 g, 8 mmol) and KOtBu (0.089 g, 0.8 mmol) in 2-propanol (3 mL) was stirred for 5 min at room temperature. An aliquot amount (1 mL) of the reaction mixture was filtered through silica column and the product conversions analysed and quantified by 1H NMR and GC–MS. Then the reaction was quenched with water (3 × 2 mL) and extracted. The organic layer gave the transfer hydrogenation product of alcohols. The same procedure was followed for ketone but reaction mixture stirred for 30 min at 60°C. The product formation was confirmed by 1H NMR and GC–MS. coredata.dc:description: Four novel N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) based Fe(II) complexes, [Fe(L1)Cp(CO)]I (1), [L1 = 3-methyl-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-benzimidazol-2-ylidene], [Fe(L2)Cp(CO)]Br (2) [L2 = 3-benzyl-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-benzimidazol-2-ylidene], [Fe(L3)Cp-(CO)]Br (3), [L3 = 3-(4-tert-butyl-benzyl)-1-(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)-benzimidazol-2-ylidene] and [Fe(L4)Cp(CO)]I (4), L4 = 1,3-di-(2- methylenepyridyl methyl)-benzimidazol-2-ylidene] have been synthesized and characterized as efficient catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds. The disappearance of 1H NMR signals at 10.09–11.78 ppm of NHC ligand confirms the complex formation via carbene coordination to low spin Fe(II) center and it is further supported by the two distinct doublets for two diastereotopic protons of the methylene group connects pyridine and benzimidazole rings. The IR spectra show ν str, 1939–1958 cm−1 for the coordinated CO, which are virtually independent of the wingtip substituents and possibly this limits the influence of those groups on the electronic properties of iron(II) center. The molecular structure of the complexes 1, 2 and 4 reveals the coordination of NHC ligand, cyclopentadiene (Cp) and CO to low spin FeII center (S = 0). The bonds Fe-Ccarbene (1.907–1.934 Å), Fe-NPy (1.995–2.019 Å), Fe−CO (1.743–1.762 Å) and Fe-Cp (2.058–2.097 Å) are almost identical in all the complexes. The bite angles CO-Fe-Ccarbene (90.9°– 113.8°) are higher than Cp-Fe-Ccarbene (92.6°–93.2°) but the bite angle CO-Fe-Npy are merely indentical in all complexes (89.7°). All the complexes showed two redox couples at 1.050 - 1.080 V and 0.560 – 0.585 V corresponds to FeII/FeIII and ligand-based redox couples respectively. The complexes exhibited the excellent transfer hydrogenation for aldehydes up to yield of 99% with the turnover frequency (TOF) of 13,680 h−1 at room temperature. The ketone substrates showed conversion of alcohols with the yield and TOF of 98% and 2264 h−1 respectively at 60 °C.
coredata.dc:title: Novel iron(II)-N-heterocyclic carbene catalysts for efficient transfer hydrogenations under mild condition
